title: Overwatch is REMOVING performance-based "SR" gains from their ladder
body:
I made a thread stating that League SHOULDN'T have outlying factors affect your lp gains. This is just further emphasizing a point I made from before. Another popular game tried this shit and it sucked. League doesn't need it. If you win, you get lp. If you lose, you lose lp. Yeah, it sucks that you can get fed and lose due to someone being stupid, but it's better than people playing sub-optimally or gimping your team comp just so you can farm lp.

Now, they're only removing it for their Diamond tier and higher, but if this is being done to *improve* Overwatch's ranked game mode, to *remove* this type of feature, clearly it's in League's best interest to not even bother.

It's really bothersome for duo bot too. Even though my ADC may play every ranked game with me, we don't get synchronized amounts of LP. I've had a few times when my ADC was anywhere from 3 to 10 LP behind, meaning at some point I was in my series and he wasn't. Thankfully we've won or lost our series consecutively each time, but had it not gone that way...

How? It would promote everyone to try their best, even when behind, with the hopes that they can maybe salvage some of the LP they'd have lost. A black and white win/loss result in this ridiculously snowball(y) meta with 15 minute /ff votes, if anything, promotes the complete opposite. "Nah, this game's over, move onto the next one," rather than playing it out for another 8 minutes, sometimes winning (especially possible in lower elos) and Learning something to strengthen players.

That's why you design it to not be a guess and to be targeted at big outliers. It should be about catching people who are clearly at the wrong rating and correcting their rating some, not nickle and dimeing people up or down every game. Which is why it doesn't really work well at high ELO. If you get that high it's very unlikely your rating is far off unless you've been literally boosted.

Not feeding is not enough to get an S. 

* If you really want the S you have to steal every ward last hit even if another player on your team found it and made the first 2-3 hits on it
* Take all the farm in whatever lane you are in even if it is not your lane
* Take buffs from jungler
* Do everything you can to get the kill even if another player on your team is about to get the kill.
* Can you push to win, but there is a lane with a ton of farm? Go get the farm to pad your creep score. 
* Is a risky teamfight about to happen that could end the game, and your score is currently good enough to get an S? Better sit it out and let your team lose it; you might lose the game but you are more likely to get an S.

This is not always strictly necessary, but it is the best way of ensuring you get an S

Is this teamwork? Hardly, but it is the behaviour riot encourages by giving S ratings based on individual ingame numbers/scores, and trying to deny it by saying it is possible without doing the above is foolish, because doing the above maximizes your probability of getting an S rating, regardless of how selfish it is.
You literally can go 0/20 with 0 CS and you will still get a chest for the champion you're playing if your fuckbuddy premade gets an S.

* ward score
* creep score
* kills
* few deaths
* assists
* objective damage

If your intention is to maximize these then the only two that benefit less from greedy play is objective damage and assists. 
And also unless you are a support it is likely that kills completely outweigh assists
It is possible to get decent scores in all of these by playing as a team, but if you wish to be sure, you should try your very best to last hit every ward, and every kill, and play more safely than what is good for your teams victory.

Other than that, if you wish to maximize them, play greedily. That way you maximize your chances of an S rating.

Laning isn't the only measure of performance.

If you:

* Get decent CS
* Have decent KDA
* Have high kill participation
* Secure or participate in securing a high number of objectives
* Have a high vision score

(read: if you're reliably getting S ranks on your champion)

..then you are probably playing the game quite well by any objective measure.

And unfortunately, that side of the story is completely tossed out when LP is decided purely by winning/losing matches. Not sure why this is such a difficult concept for Riot to understand. Nobody should ever have to play tens or hundreds of extra games due to the incompetence of others. At least, as others have said, your individual skill as a player should somehow be taken into account when it comes to calculating LP.

And yet isn't HOT's adding something like this to ranked? So it's a different story maybe depending on the TYPE of game. 3rd person vs 1st person, laning-based vs non-laning-based game. Also, there's no itemization and leveling up abilities in overwatch, but there is in league and hots. If it can be done PROPERLY, I am entirely in favor of performance-based Ip gains or losses. If I'm getting bot lanes that go 1/7/0 in laning phase, shove blindly without warding, ignore mia's and danger pings, and FORCE fights vs enemies they fed (as though they stand a better chance of winning now that the enemy has 1500 gold more in items and they couldn't win when it was even in gold); I want to lose less Ip for this if I perform above average. The problem is, much of this can be immeasurable by statistics. Kda can be a horrible indicator. Gold farmed - well, we've seen in the pro scene some of the best adc's don't actually have the highest gpm, but when you look at their opponent's gpm, it is half of what is expected from that opponent because that best adc zones the opponent off farm so well.
Similarly, you might have low kill participation, but be winning a difficult matchup while being camped by the enemy jg or constantly roamed on by the enemy mid and bot laners or top laner. So it LOOKS like you did little to help your team, but in reality, you absorbed a TON of pressure, remained relevant, kept up map pressure as much as possible, and still won 2v2's or 1v1's whenever not being ganked. Or maybe, you got your opponent's tower really low w/o any help from your team, but then due to need for lane rotations an inopportune fight causing you to have to leave, you miss out on killing the tower and the gold it gives; then it just goes into stats as an accomplishment by minions or your teammates while it doesn't look half as amazing in your stat line even though you did most of the work. Conversely, you could feed all of laning phase, get carried by your teammates mid game, be relevant in terms of damage by late game, carry ONE fight all game, and win. Then, if you'd "ks'd" well in those mid game fights to become relevant, you have an amazing kda; meanwhile, your teammate who had to carry those midgame fights and die every time so your team would come out ahead has a mediocre kda by game's end even though he/she did much more work than you. Thus, your Ip gain might be inflated while his/hers might be lower than it should be based on actual performance. Stuff like that is the only problem I can see with making Ip gain/loss performance-based.

Afkers should lose more LP and feeders. A simple system that can determine how long you sitting around fountain for more then 1min and if you going 0/10/0 showing you not helping with assists and such makes it kinda obvious u feeding on purpose.

League has probably the most flawed ranking system of any competitive game I've ever played. There are so many people of varying skill levels and so many variables that the system can only be so accurate when it comes to judging how good you are. I have a dozen friends that play at all levels (bronze-diamond) and while a few of them definitely belong where they are I can honestly say most of them are pretty even skill wise. Ranked is more about who's willing to put in the time and effort to move up as opposed to who's actually better. I've also spectated literally hundreds of games over the years (especially back when it was easily accessible on the client) and I see absolutely no difference in play between gold and diamond games. Hell, I've even watched challenger/pro players in solo queue and it's nothing like people would expect (LCS) and even those games become massive blood baths of people feeding with low cs counts. Don't get me wrong I'm not saying this is written fact, there are definitely outliers of extremely skilled (or unskilled players) in ranks they may or may not deserve to be in.
I'm unaware of these "SR" gains. Explain?

You get more SR (LP in League) or lose less SR by doing certain actions better than other players playing the same hero. For example, there were several people playing only Mercy with around 35% win rate in Grandmaster (basically Challenger) who got there solely by hiding and not participating in the game and then using their ult to revive their entire team at any time they could, even if it was a total waste and it throws the game. Sure, they got a lot of big revives off, but a lot of them were detrimental to the team or complete wastes. The game didn't consider that though and just looked at the big numbers.
To put it in League terms, imagine if you could get to Challenger as Soraka by just staying in fountain and ulting every time your team got low HP.

Because if it was ever implemented it'd be a trash idea because of outliers like that

Overwatch had to keep tweaking ranked so SR gains on every hero was balanced and it still penalizes you if you swap heroes which is a core game mechanic because it only cares about your scores for the average for that hero.  It makes competitive rank you wildly low unless you're a one trick and a bunch of one tricks are getting temp bans for "Refusing to communicate" so its a fucking mess overall.  

Now given everyone selects roles beforehand and you get one champion the one trick thing is less relevant but if there were metrics like wards placed or successful ults giving you bonus LP you could end up with scenarios like he mentioned, where a Soraka warding in shitty spots but rapidly and pressing R in fountain to boost the healing # would basically reduce LP loss or increase LP gains despite not actually factoring game contribution, merely your average compared to other players on that champ.  Riot has no plans to implement this system but anyone that suggests this should be aware of the consequences of trying to implement this mess of a feature just to buffer LP loss in hard games.
